problem: {name}’s ducks lay {x} eggs per day. She eats {y} for breakfast every morning and bakes muffins for her {people} every day with {z}. She sells the remainder at the {place} daily for ${a} per fresh duck egg. How much in dollars does she make every day at the farmers' market?
A robe takes {x} bolts of blue fiber and {y} that much white fiber.  How many bolts in total does it take?

{name} has been selling her {people}'s collection of {x} books for three years. Each book sells at {y}$, and she sold {z} times as many books in the first year as she has sold in the current year. There are currently {a} unsold books, and her sales number this year is {b}. What's the total amount of money she earned in the second year?
solution:
If her sales in the current year are {b}, she sold {b}*{z} = <<{b}*{z}={books_first}>>{books_first} books in the first year.
The total number of books sold in the first and current year is {books_first}+{b} = <<{books_first}+{b}={books_first_cur}>>{books_first_cur}.
The total number of books sold in the second year is {x} of the original number of books - {books_first_cur} sold books - {a} unsold books = <<{x}-{books_first_cur}-{a}={books_second}>>{books_second} books.
If each book sells at {y}$, then she earned {y}*{books_second} = $<<{y}*{books_second}={ans}>>{ans} in the second year
#### {ans}

problem: {name} is planting tulips. He can fit {x} red tulips in a row and {y} blue tulips in a row. If {name} buys {z} red tulips and {a} blue tulips, how many rows of flowers will he plant?
solution:
First, divide the number of red tulips by the number of red tulips per row: {z} / {x} = <<{z}/{x}={red_rows}>>{red_rows} rows.
Next, divide the number of blue tulips by the number of blue tulips per row: {a} / {y} = <<{a}/{y}={blue_rows}>>{blue_rows} rows.
Now add the number of rows of each color to find the total: {red_rows} + {blue_rows} = <<{red_rows}+{blue_rows}={ans}>>{ans} rows.
#### {ans}

problem: {name} is practicing for his role in a theater production. He has to memorize his lines for two scenes and the lyrics to one solo song. His solo song has {x} lines in the lyrics. The first scene has {y} times the number of lines, but only {z}/{a} of them are his lines. The second scene has {b} more lines than the song, and {c}/{d} of them are his. How many lines does {name} have to memorize?
solution:
The first scene has {y} times the number of lines as his solo song, so it has {y} * {x} = <<{y}*{x}={first_lines}>>{first_lines} lines.
A {z}/{a} of them are {name}’s lines, so he has to memorize {z} * {first_lines} / {a} = <<{z}*{first_lines}/{a}={his_first_lines}>>{his_first_lines} lines.
The second scene has {x} + {b} = <<{x}+{b}={second_lines}>>{second_lines} lines.
{c}/{d} of the second scene’s lines are {name}’s, so he has to memorize {c} * {second_lines} / {d} = <<{c}*{second_lines}/{d}={his_second_lines}>>{his_second_lines} lines.
{name} has to memorize his entire solo song, so he has to memorize {x} + {his_first_lines} + {his_second_lines} = <<{x}+{his_first_lines}+{his_second_lines}={ans}>>{ans} lines in all.
#### {ans}

problem: {name} takes care of {x} dogs.  Each dog takes {y} hours a day to walk and take care of their business.  How many hours a week does he spend taking care of dogs?
{name} is solving a {x}-piece jigsaw puzzle. She places 1/{y} of the pieces on the board, then her {people} places 1/{z} of the remaining pieces. How many jigsaw pieces are left to be placed?
solution:
{name} has placed {x} pieces / {y} = <<{x}/{y}={pop_pieces}>>{pop_pieces} pieces.
This means there are {x} – {pop_pieces} = <<{x}-{pop_pieces}={rest}>>{rest} pieces remaining.
Her {people} therefore places {rest} / {z} = <<{rest}/{z}={mom_pieces}>>{mom_pieces} pieces.
This leaves a total of {rest} – {mom_pieces} = <<{rest}-{mom_pieces}={ans}>>{ans} jigsaw pieces left to be placed.
#### {ans}

problem: {name} owns a flower shop. He sells a sunflower that costs ${x} each and a bouquet of sunflower that costs ${y}. If {name} earned ${z} from the sunflower and ${a} from the bouquet per day, and if each bouquet has {b} sunflowers, how many sunflowers was {name} able to sell after {c} days?
solution:
{name} sold ${a} / ${y} = <<{a}/{y}={num_boq}>>{num_boq} bouquets of sunflower.
So he was able to sell a total of {b} x {num_boq} = <<{b}*{num_boq}={num_sun}>>{num_sun} sunflowers from the bouquets.
And he was able to sell a total of ${z}/${x}= <<{z}/{x}={sun}>>{sun} Sunflowers.
The sum of sunflowers {name} was able to sell is {num_sun} + {sun} = <<{num_sun}+{sun}={tot_sun}>>{tot_sun}.
Therefore, the total of sunflowers he sold after {c} days is {tot_sun} x {c} = <<{tot_sun}*{c}={ans}>>{ans}.
#### {ans}

problem: {name} bought a CD for ${x}, and a headphone set. In total, he paid ${y}. How many more CDs would {name} have been able to buy if he had decided not to buy the headphone set?

The employees of Google went on a day trip. {x} buses were rented that have the capacity of holding {y} employees. {z} minibusses that can hold {a} employees, and {b} minivans that can hold {c} employees. How many employees can join the day trip?
solution:
{y} x {x} = <<{y}*{x}={bus}>>{bus} employees can ride on the bus.
{a} x {z} = <<{a}*{z}={mini}>>{mini} employees can ride on the minibusses.
{c} x {b} = <<{c}*{b}={van}>>{van} employees can ride on the minivans.
Therefore {bus} + {mini} + {van} = <<{bus}+{mini}+{van}={ans}>>{ans} employees can join the day trip.
#### {ans}
